First Transatlantic Flight
May 31, 1919 • Plymouth, England
GRENADA

TIC COUNT
31 MAY '84

International Tributes to the History of Flight
First Transatlantic Flight
The U.S. and British navies had painstakingly mapped
Read was accorded a hero's welcome by the British,
out the plan. It was put to the test on May 16, 1919,

when three U.S. Navy Curtiss flying boats took off
success.
from Far Rockaway, New York. Their goal - to make
The full-color cachet pictures the Curtiss NC-4 in
the first transatlantic crossing by air.
flight over Lisbon. The plane was about 68½ feet long,
with a wingspan of almost 126 feet. Total flying time
Only one pilot successfully made the trip, Lieuten-
ant Commander Albert C. Read flying the NC-4. In
Newfoundland, he had to jettison supplies in order
to take off. Then, dense fog set in over the ocean.
The other planes were forced to land in the sea, but
Read triumphed over the elements and managed to
bring his plane safely into Horta, Azores on May 17.
Ten days later, he flew onto Lisbon, Portugal and
from there, on May 31, to Plymouth, England, the
symbolic end to this historic bridging of the Atlantic.
for the first transatlantic crossing, from New York to
Lisbon, was 25 hours, 1 minute.
Mint Stamp: The mint stamp on this Cover was issued
by Grenada in 1983. It pictures the Curtiss NC-4 flying
boat, originally commissioned by the U.S. Navy for
anti-submarine operations during World War I.
Postmark: This Cover was postmarked in Plymouth,
England, the last stop for the NC-4, on May 31, 1984,
the anniversary of the first transatlantic flight.
© Postal Commemorative Society
Printed in U.S.A.

properties.sfomuseum:description: Airmail flight cover, part of International Tributes to the History of Flight series by the Postal Commemorative Society; white envelope with full color illustration cachet and inset stamp commemorating first/inaugural transatlantic flight on May 31, 1919, in Plymouth, England, by Lieutenant Commander Albert C. Read, U.S. Navy, with Curtiss NC-4 flying boat; commemorative cancellation stamp dated May 31, 1984 in Plymouth; includes information on reverse.
properties.wof:name: airmail flight cover: First transatlantic flight commemorative
